name: HttpRequest
comment:
A server-side object that contains the content of and information about an HTTP request.

Note: Check out the http_server package, which makes working with the low-level dart:io HTTP server subsystem easier.

HttpRequest objects are generated by an dart-io.HttpServer, which listens for HTTP requests on a specific host and port. For each request received, the HttpServer, which is a dart-async.Stream, generates an HttpRequest object and adds it to the stream.

An HttpRequest object delivers the body content of the request as a stream of byte lists. The object also contains information about the request, such as the method, URI, and headers.

In the following code, an HttpServer listens for HTTP requests. When the server receives a request, it uses the HttpRequest object's method property to dispatch requests.

final HOST = InternetAddress.LOOPBACK_IP_V4;
final PORT = 80;

HttpServer.bind(HOST, PORT).then((_server) {
  _server.listen((HttpRequest request) {
    switch (request.method) {
      case 'GET':
        handleGetRequest(request);
        break;
      case 'POST':
        ...
    }
  },
  onError: handleError);    // listen() failed.
}).catchError(handleError);

An HttpRequest object provides access to the associated dart-io.HttpResponse object through the response property. The server writes its response to the body of the HttpResponse object. For example, here's a function that responds to a request:

void handleGetRequest(HttpRequest req) {
  HttpResponse res = req.response;
  res.write('Received request ${req.method}: ${req.uri.path}');
  res.close();
}

certificate.name: certificate
certificate.comment:
The client certificate of the client making the request.

This value is null if the connection is not a secure TLS or SSL connection, or if the server does not request a client certificate, or if the client does not provide one.

connectionInfo.name: connectionInfo
connectionInfo.comment:
Information about the client connection.

Returns null if the socket is not available.

contentLength.name: contentLength
contentLength.comment:
The content length of the request body.

If the size of the request body is not known in advance, this value is -1.

cookies.name: cookies
cookies.comment: The cookies in the request, from the Cookie headers.

method.name: method
method.comment: The method, such as 'GET' or 'POST', for the request.

persistentConnection.name: persistentConnection
persistentConnection.comment: The persistent connection state signaled by the client.

protocolVersion.name: protocolVersion
protocolVersion.comment: The HTTP protocol version used in the request, either "1.0" or "1.1".

requestedUri.name: requestedUri
requestedUri.comment:
The requested URI for the request.

The returend URI is reconstructed by using http-header fields, to access otherwise lost information, e.g. host and scheme.

To reconstruct the scheme, first 'X-Forwarded-Proto' is checked, and then falling back to server type.

To reconstruct the host, fisrt 'X-Forwarded-Host' is checked, then 'Host' and finally calling back to server.

response.name: response
response.comment:
The dart-io.HttpResponse object, used for sending back the response to the client.

If the dart-io.HttpRequest.contentLength of the body isn't 0, and the body isn't being read, any write calls on the dart-io.HttpResponse automatically drain the request body.

session.name: session
session.comment:
The session for the given request.

If the session is being initialized by this call, isNew is true for the returned session. See HttpServer.sessionTimeout on how to change default timeout.

uri.name: uri
uri.comment:
The URI for the request.

This provides access to the path, query string, and fragment identifier for the request.

first.name: first
first.comment:
Returns the first element of the stream.

Stops listening to the stream after the first element has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after the first element. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this getter.

If an error event occurs before the first data event, the resulting future is completed with that error.

If this stream is empty (a done event occurs before the first data event), the resulting future completes with a dart-core.StateError.

Except for the type of the error, this method is equivalent to this.elementAt(0).

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides dart-io.HttpRequest.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

isBroadcast.name: isBroadcast
isBroadcast.comment: Reports whether this stream is a broadcast stream.

isEmpty.name: isEmpty
isEmpty.comment:
Reports whether this stream contains any elements.

Stops listening to the stream after the first element has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after the first element. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this getter.

last.name: last
last.comment:
Returns the last element of the stream.

If an error event occurs before the first data event, the resulting future is completed with that error.

If this stream is empty (a done event occurs before the first data event), the resulting future completes with a dart-core.StateError.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

single.name: single
single.comment:
Returns the single element.

If an error event occurs before or after the first data event, the resulting future is completed with that error.

If this is empty or has more than one element throws a dart-core.StateError.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and dart-io.HttpRequest.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the dart-io.HttpRequest.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

any.name: any
any.comment:
Checks whether dart-io.HttpRequest.any.test accepts any element provided by this stream.

Completes the dart-async.Future when the answer is known.

If this stream reports an error, the dart-async.Future reports that error.

Stops listening to the stream after the first matching element has been found.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after this element. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

asBroadcastStream.name: asBroadcastStream
asBroadcastStream.comment:
Returns a multi-subscription stream that produces the same events as this.

If this stream is already a broadcast stream, it is returned unmodified.

If this stream is single-subscription, return a new stream that allows multiple subscribers. It will subscribe to this stream when its first subscriber is added, and will stay subscribed until this stream ends, or a callback cancels the subscription.

If dart-io.HttpRequest.asBroadcastStream.onListen is provided, it is called with a subscription-like object that represents the underlying subscription to this stream. It is possible to pause, resume or cancel the subscription during the call to dart-io.HttpRequest.asBroadcastStream.onListen. It is not possible to change the event handlers, including using dart-async.StreamSubscription.asFuture.

If dart-io.HttpRequest.asBroadcastStream.onCancel is provided, it is called in a similar way to dart-io.HttpRequest.asBroadcastStream.onListen when the returned stream stops having listener. If it later gets a new listener, the dart-io.HttpRequest.asBroadcastStream.onListen function is called again.

Use the callbacks, for example, for pausing the underlying subscription while having no subscribers to prevent losing events, or canceling the subscription when there are no listeners.

asyncExpand.name: asyncExpand
asyncExpand.comment:
Creates a new stream with the events of a stream per original event.

This acts like dart-io.HttpRequest.expand, except that dart-io.HttpRequest.asyncExpand.convert returns a dart-async.Stream instead of an dart-core.Iterable. The events of the returned stream becomes the events of the returned stream, in the order they are produced.

If dart-io.HttpRequest.asyncExpand.convert returns null, no value is put on the output stream, just as if it returned an empty stream.

asyncMap.name: asyncMap
asyncMap.comment:
Creates a new stream with each data event of this stream asynchronously mapped to a new event.

This acts like dart-io.HttpRequest.map, except that dart-io.HttpRequest.asyncMap.convert may return a dart-async.Future, and in that case, the stream waits for that future to complete before continuing with its result.

contains.name: contains
contains.comment:
Checks whether dart-io.HttpRequest.contains.needle occurs in the elements provided by this stream.

Completes the dart-async.Future when the answer is known. If this stream reports an error, the dart-async.Future will report that error.

distinct.name: distinct
distinct.comment:
Skips data events if they are equal to the previous data event.

The returned stream provides the same events as this stream, except that it never provides two consequtive data events that are equal.

Equality is determined by the provided dart-io.HttpRequest.distinct.equals method. If that is omitted, the '==' operator on the last provided data element is used.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

drain.name: drain
drain.comment:
Discards all data on the stream, but signals when it's done or an error occured.

When subscribing using dart-io.HttpRequest.drain, cancelOnError will be true. This means that the future will complete with the first error on the stream and then cancel the subscription.

In case of a done event the future completes with the given dart-io.HttpRequest.drain.futureValue.

elementAt.name: elementAt
elementAt.comment:
Returns the value of the dart-io.HttpRequest.elementAt.indexth data event of this stream.

Stops listening to the stream after the dart-io.HttpRequest.elementAt.indexth data event has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after these elements. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

If an error event occurs before the value is found, the future completes with this error.

If a done event occurs before the value is found, the future completes with a dart-core.RangeError.

every.name: every
every.comment:
Checks whether dart-io.HttpRequest.every.test accepts all elements provided by this stream.

Completes the dart-async.Future when the answer is known. If this stream reports an error, the dart-async.Future will report that error.

expand.name: expand
expand.comment:
Creates a new stream from this stream that converts each element into zero or more events.

Each incoming event is converted to an dart-core.Iterable of new events, and each of these new events are then sent by the returned stream in order.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

firstWhere.name: firstWhere
firstWhere.comment:
Finds the first element of this stream matching dart-io.HttpRequest.firstWhere.test.

Returns a future that is filled with the first element of this stream that dart-io.HttpRequest.firstWhere.test returns true for.

If no such element is found before this stream is done, and a dart-io.HttpRequest.firstWhere.defaultValue function is provided, the result of calling dart-io.HttpRequest.firstWhere.defaultValue becomes the value of the future.

Stops listening to the stream after the first matching element has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after the first element that matches the predicate. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

If an error occurs, or if this stream ends without finding a match and with no dart-io.HttpRequest.firstWhere.defaultValue function provided, the future will receive an error.

fold.name: fold
fold.comment: Reduces a sequence of values by repeatedly applying dart-io.HttpRequest.fold.combine.

forEach.name: forEach
forEach.comment:
Executes dart-io.HttpRequest.forEach.action on each data event of the stream.

Completes the returned dart-async.Future when all events of the stream have been processed. Completes the future with an error if the stream has an error event, or if dart-io.HttpRequest.forEach.action throws.

handleError.name: handleError
handleError.comment:
Creates a wrapper Stream that intercepts some errors from this stream.

If this stream sends an error that matches dart-io.HttpRequest.handleError.test, then it is intercepted by the handle function.

The dart-io.HttpRequest.handleError.onError callback must be of type void onError(error) or void onError(error, StackTrace stackTrace). Depending on the function type the the stream either invokes dart-io.HttpRequest.handleError.onError with or without a stack trace. The stack trace argument might be null if the stream itself received an error without stack trace.

An asynchronous error e is matched by a test function if test(e) returns true. If dart-io.HttpRequest.handleError.test is omitted, every error is considered matching.

If the error is intercepted, the handle function can decide what to do with it. It can throw if it wants to raise a new (or the same) error, or simply return to make the stream forget the error.

If you need to transform an error into a data event, use the more generic dart-io.HttpRequest.transform to handle the event by writing a data event to the output sink

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

join.name: join
join.comment:
Collects string of data events' string representations.

If dart-io.HttpRequest.join.separator is provided, it is inserted between any two elements.

Any error in the stream causes the future to complete with that error. Otherwise it completes with the collected string when the "done" event arrives.

lastWhere.name: lastWhere
lastWhere.comment:
Finds the last element in this stream matching dart-io.HttpRequest.lastWhere.test.

As dart-io.HttpRequest.firstWhere, except that the last matching element is found. That means that the result cannot be provided before this stream is done.

listen.name: listen
listen.comment:
Adds a subscription to this stream.

On each data event from this stream, the subscriber's dart-io.HttpRequest.listen.onData handler is called. If dart-io.HttpRequest.listen.onData is null, nothing happens.

On errors from this stream, the dart-io.HttpRequest.listen.onError handler is given a object describing the error.

The dart-io.HttpRequest.listen.onError callback must be of type void onError(error) or void onError(error, StackTrace stackTrace). If dart-io.HttpRequest.listen.onError accepts two arguments it is called with the stack trace (which could be null if the stream itself received an error without stack trace). Otherwise it is called with just the error object.

If this stream closes, the dart-io.HttpRequest.listen.onDone handler is called.

If dart-io.HttpRequest.listen.cancelOnError is true, the subscription is ended when the first error is reported. The default is false.

map.name: map
map.comment:
Creates a new stream that converts each element of this stream to a new value using the dart-io.HttpRequest.map.convert function.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
dart-io.HttpRequest.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to dart-io.HttpRequest.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If dart-io.HttpRequest.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of dart-io.HttpRequest.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

pipe.name: pipe
pipe.comment: Binds this stream as the input of the provided dart-async.StreamConsumer.

reduce.name: reduce
reduce.comment: Reduces a sequence of values by repeatedly applying dart-io.HttpRequest.reduce.combine.

singleWhere.name: singleWhere
singleWhere.comment:
Finds the single element in this stream matching dart-io.HttpRequest.singleWhere.test.

Like lastMatch, except that it is an error if more than one matching element occurs in the stream.

skip.name: skip
skip.comment:
Skips the first dart-io.HttpRequest.skip.count data events from this stream.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

skipWhile.name: skipWhile
skipWhile.comment:
Skip data events from this stream while they are matched by dart-io.HttpRequest.skipWhile.test.

Error and done events are provided by the returned stream unmodified.

Starting with the first data event where dart-io.HttpRequest.skipWhile.test returns false for the event data, the returned stream will have the same events as this stream.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

take.name: take
take.comment:
Provides at most the first n values of this stream.

Forwards the first n data events of this stream, and all error events, to the returned stream, and ends with a done event.

If this stream produces fewer than dart-io.HttpRequest.take.count values before it's done, so will the returned stream.

Stops listening to the stream after the first n elements have been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after these elements. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

takeWhile.name: takeWhile
takeWhile.comment:
Forwards data events while dart-io.HttpRequest.takeWhile.test is successful.

The returned stream provides the same events as this stream as long as dart-io.HttpRequest.takeWhile.test returns true for the event data. The stream is done when either this stream is done, or when this stream first provides a value that dart-io.HttpRequest.takeWhile.test doesn't accept.

Stops listening to the stream after the accepted elements.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after these elements. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

timeout.name: timeout
timeout.comment:
Creates a new stream with the same events as this stream.

Whenever more than dart-io.HttpRequest.timeout.timeLimit passes between two events from this stream, the dart-io.HttpRequest.timeout.onTimeout function is called.

The countdown doesn't start until the returned stream is listened to. The countdown is reset every time an event is forwarded from this stream, or when the stream is paused and resumed.

The dart-io.HttpRequest.timeout.onTimeout function is called with one argument: an dart-async.EventSink that allows putting events into the returned stream. This EventSink is only valid during the call to onTimeout.

If onTimeout is omitted, a timeout will just put a dart-async.TimeoutException into the error channel of the returned stream.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

toList.name: toList
toList.comment: Collects the data of this stream in a dart-core.List.

toSet.name: toSet
toSet.comment: Collects the data of this stream in a dart-core.Set.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

transform.name: transform
transform.comment:
Chains this stream as the input of the provided dart-async.StreamTransformer.

Returns the result of streamTransformer.bind itself.

where.name: where
where.comment:
Creates a new stream from this stream that discards some data events.

The new stream sends the same error and done events as this stream, but it only sends the data events that satisfy the dart-io.HttpRequest.where.test.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.
